Hunters Quay: 11â12 August |competitors = 65 |nations = 5 |teams = 13 |gold =   |goldNOC = GBR |silver =   |silverNOC = BEL |silver2 =   |silverNOC2 = SWE |prev = [[Sailing at the 1900 Summer Olympics|1900]] |next = [[Sailing at the 1912 Summer Olympics|1912]] }} '''[[Sailing|Sailing/Yachting]]''' is a [[Olympic sport]] starting from the Games of the 1st [[Olympiad]] ([[Sailing at the 1896 Summer Olympics|1896 Olympics]] in Athens {{GRE}}). With the exception of [[1904 Summer Olympics|1904]] and possible [[1916 Summer Olympics|1916]] sailing was always a part of the Olympic program. The Sailing program of 1908 was open for a total of five sailing classes (disciplines). It turned out that no entries were made in the 15 Metre. The planned venue of all races, named ''matches'' was Ryde, [[Isle of Wight]]. == Venue == {{Infobox settlement | name = [[Royal Victoria Yacht Club]] | image_seal = | image_skyline = | image_flag = Burgee Royal Victoria Yacht Club.png | pushpin_map_caption = | latd = 50 |latm = 43 |lats = 37 |latNS = N | longd = 1 |longm = 9 |longs = 42 |longEW = W }} {{Infobox settlement | name = [[Clyde Corinthian Yacht Club]] | image_seal = | image_skyline = Clyde 1908 Race Committee.png | image_flag = Burgee Clyde Corinthian Yacht Club.png | pushpin_map_caption = | latd = 55 |latm = 58 |lats = 30 |latNS = N | longd = 4 |longm = 54 |longs = 30 |longEW = W }} At the 1907 The Hague Conference of the IOC Ryde at the Isle of Wight was appointed to host the sailing regattas, for all classes, of the Games of the IVth Olympiad. However when there were only British entries for the 12 Metre matches, and both yacht were located at the Firth of Clyde, the decision was made to use Hunterâs Quay as a second venue. At Ryde the race committee used the available shipping buoys as marks for the courses. 16 [[Nautical miles|nm]] for the 8 Metre and 13 [[Nautical miles|nm]] for the 6 and 7 Metre. == CompetitionThe number of entries was not high. This was because the decision of the classes to use was taken less than one year before the games. Building wooden boats, in a class not proven yet, varying in length between 12 and 30 meters, practice with them and ship them to the games in time was for many owners a challenge. This had a lot to do with national traditions as well as with the fact that there were no standardized boat types with uniform building instructions and measurements. Also a lot of development was done in the area of boat design and boat building. The shape of a boat, specifically its length, its weight and its sail area, are major parameters that determine the boat's speed. Several initiatives were started to create a formula that made it possible to have boats race each other without having to calculate the final result. But the different countries initially could not agree on an international system. At the Olympics of 1900 it was clear that sailing was not ready for international competition, and something had to be done. In 1906 international meetings were organize to solve the problem. Finally in Paris, October 1907 the first [[International Rule (sailing)|International Rule]] was ratified. Delegates from this meeting went on to form the [[International Yacht Racing Union]] (IYRU), the precursor to the present [[International Sailing Federation]] (ISAF). The agreed formula gives a result in meters (Metre). The duchess of Westminster also distributed the diploma's of special merit to the competitors of the other Olympic sports on July, 25 1908. * The matches at Ryde were held in light air conditions. * All members of a team had to be a citizen of the country they represent. However the boats used did not have to be build in the same country that the team was representing since the Olympic games are considered a test of skills and handling for the team and no a test of the yacht.
